rows.title: Notice how you feel

transcript.eng:
Hello! How are you feeling right now? Happy, sad, angry, excited, worried?

Notice where you feel it in your body. Notice what thoughts are connected to that feeling. Take a deep breath.

Thank yourself for taking the time to check in with your feelings and thoughts!

rows.transcript:
Hello! How are you feeling right now? Happy, sad, angry, excited, worried?

Notice where you feel it in your body. Notice what thoughts are connected to that feeling. Take a deep breath.

Thank yourself for taking the time to check in with your feelings and thoughts!

text_1.eng: Take a moment to check in with yourself.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Wonderful, I am so happy things are going well.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Some days will have their challenges. That is okay. You are on the right path!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Sorry that things are difficult now. It is completely normal to struggle sometimes. Remember that you are not alone!

rows.text_1: Take a moment to check in with yourself.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Wonderful, I am so happy things are going well.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Some days will have their challenges. That is okay. You are on the right path!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Sorry that things are difficult now. It is completely normal to struggle sometimes. Remember that you are not alone!

section_1_text.eng: This module includes content that may be sensitive. You can check it out by yourself first. This will prepare you well for sharing the content with your teen and others afterwards.

rows.section_1_text: This module includes content that may be sensitive. You can check it out by yourself first. This will prepare you well for sharing the content with your teen and others afterwards.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's topic is about body changes and intimate relationships.

Teenagers go through a lot of changes, both in their bodies and in how they feel and experience the world. By speaking with them you can help them handle this change as well.

Let your teen know you may not have all the answers, but you are there to support them and find solutions together. That way your teen knows you are there to listen and talk. You will not judge or shame them and can support them to make healthy and confident decisions.

text_2.eng:
**Think back to your own teenage years:**

- Did you ever experience a difficult situation as a teenager around body changes? And what about relationships?
- What kind of support or information do you wish you had at the time?
- Do you think your teen may be experiencing any challenges in these areas?

media_title.eng: Why is discussing body and intimate relationships with your teen important?

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is body changes and intimate relationships.

Discussing body and intimate relationships with your child can be difficult. However, it is important to have these discussions in order for your teen to understand that this stage of life is normal. This will help them to acknowledge the changes in their bodies and be able to take positive decisions regarding intimate relationships.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's topic is about body changes and intimate relationships.

Teenagers go through a lot of changes, both in their bodies and in how they feel and experience the world. By speaking with them you can help them handle this change as well.

Let your teen know you may not have all the answers, but you are there to support them and find solutions together. That way your teen knows you are there to listen and talk. You will not judge or shame them and can support them to make healthy and confident decisions.
rows.text_2:
**Think back to your own teenage years:**

- Did you ever experience a difficult situation as a teenager around body changes? And what about relationships?
- What kind of support or information do you wish you had at the time?
- Do you think your teen may be experiencing any challenges in these areas?
rows.media_title: Why is discussing body and intimate relationships with your teen important?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is body changes and intimate relationships.

Discussing body and intimate relationships with your child can be difficult. However, it is important to have these discussions in order for your teen to understand that this stage of life is normal. This will help them to acknowledge the changes in their bodies and be able to take positive decisions regarding intimate relationships.

media_title.eng: Placeholder text - Anna - we need a media title for this caregiver testimonial

media_transcript.eng:
Thanks to the app, I can now talk to my son about all these changes that he is going through with his body and emotions and relationships. We were both not comfortable bringing it up before, but the practical examples in the app made it possible for us to start talking. And I was really surprised by how many questions and experiences my son already has, even though he is only 14!

Now he can come to me if there is something happening at school or if he is not sure how to handle something. The other day he even told me that some of his friends were making fun of him because he does not have a girlfriend yet, so we talked about it and I could explain to him that it is important to focus on school first and that it is never okay for someone to pressure him to have a relationship.

rows.media_title: Placeholder text - Anna - we need a media title for this caregiver testimonial
rows.media_transcript:
Thanks to the app, I can now talk to my son about all these changes that he is going through with his body and emotions and relationships. We were both not comfortable bringing it up before, but the practical examples in the app made it possible for us to start talking. And I was really surprised by how many questions and experiences my son already has, even though he is only 14!

Now he can come to me if there is something happening at school or if he is not sure how to handle something. The other day he even told me that some of his friends were making fun of him because he does not have a girlfriend yet, so we talked about it and I could explain to him that it is important to focus on school first and that it is never okay for someone to pressure him to have a relationship.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Teenagers can get information about sex from school, their friends, home or social media. This information may not always be right or suitable for their age and situation.

Parents and teenagers can feel uncomfortable when topics around ‚Äòsex‚Äô are mentioned. They may even get into arguments, especially when parents do not approve of their teen‚Äôs behaviour.

Let‚Äôs look at an example of when @data.characters.female_child_4.name and @data.characters.female_caregiver_2.name faced this challenege.

text_2.eng: @data.characters.female_child_4.name  is on her way to leave the house looking very pretty.

character_1_text.eng: Where are you going looking like that?

character_2_text.eng: I am going out with some of my friends.

Teenagers can get information about sex from school, their friends, home or social media. This information may not always be right or suitable for their age and situation.

Parents and teenagers can feel uncomfortable when topics around ‚Äòsex‚Äô are mentioned. They may even get into arguments, especially when parents do not approve of their teen‚Äôs behaviour.

Let‚Äôs look at an example of when @data.characters.female_child_4.name and @data.characters.female_caregiver_2.name faced this challenege.
rows.text_2: @data.characters.female_child_4.name  is on her way to leave the house looking very pretty.
rows.character_1_text: Where are you going looking like that?
rows.character_2_text: I am going out with some of my friends.

text_2.eng: @data.characters.female_child_4.name  accidentally drops her bag, and a packet of condoms falls out.

character_1_text.eng: What is that @data.characters.female_child_4.name ? Condoms? Why are you carrying those in your bag? Where did you get them?!

character_2_text.eng: I got it from one of the girls at school today. We were talking about safe sex and she said she uses birth control so that she does not get pregnant.

rows.text_2: @data.characters.female_child_4.name  accidentally drops her bag, and a packet of condoms falls out.
rows.character_1_text: What is that @data.characters.female_child_4.name ? Condoms? Why are you carrying those in your bag? Where did you get them?!
rows.character_2_text: I got it from one of the girls at school today. We were talking about safe sex and she said she uses birth control so that she does not get pregnant.

character_1_text.eng: What is this talk of sex in my house! You are too young‚Ä¶

rows.character_1_text: What is this talk of sex in my house! You are too young‚Ä¶

character_1_text.eng: No, no, no, @data.characters.female_child_4.name ! I will not have this discussion with you. Is that what you do at school? Talking about things not suited for your age instead of focusing on school? You won‚Äôt go out with those friends of yours anymore. You want to bring shame in this home. Come here now! I am going to hit you. Stupid girl!

character_2_text.eng: No @data.characters.female_caregiver_2.name, please don‚Äôt hit me, it is not what you think!

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let's think about what happened in this story.

quiz_1_question.eng: Why do you think @data.characters.female_caregiver_2.name reacted the way she did?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: She was shocked that @data.characters.female_child_4.name  had condoms.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
It is possible she felt this way and then reacted harshly.

When we are angry or scared, we can say or do things that hurt others and harm our relationships.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: She felt disrespected and angry at @data.characters.female_child_4.name .

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng:
It is possible she felt this way and then reacted harshly.

When we are angry or scared, we can say or do things that hurt others and harm our relationships.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: She was scared @data.characters.female_child_4.name  was already having sex.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
It is possible she felt this way and then reacted harshly.

When we are angry or scared, we can say or do things that hurt others and harm our relationships.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: She felt ashamed to talk about sex.

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng:
It is possible she felt this way and then reacted harshly.

When we are angry or scared, we can say or do things that hurt others and harm our relationships.

quiz_2_option_1_text.eng: @data.characters.female_child_4.name  may not trust @data.characters.female_caregiver_2.name in the future

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, all of these are true. After this argument, @data.characters.female_child_4.name  is likely to look for information and advice from other places (also if something goes wrong with a relationship or in her life).

She may get into situations that are not healthy or safe, and may not want to talk to @data.characters.female_caregiver_2.name about it even if she has questions or needs help. She may feel worried that @data.characters.female_caregiver_2.name will judge her choices or feel ashamed of her.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: @data.characters.female_child_4.name  may not ask @data.characters.female_caregiver_2.name questions or advice if she has a problem.

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: @data.characters.female_child_4.name  may make bad decisions out of anger.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
We saw how challenging it was for @data.characters.female_child_4.name and @data.characters.female_caregiver_2.name.

It can be hard for parents and teens to talk about boyfriends and girlfriends.

Let‚Äôs look at an example of how this can happen calmly.

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.female_caregiver_1.name, can I talk to you about something?

character_2_text.eng: (calmly) Sure, my darling. What is the matter?

rows.text_1_facilitator:
We saw how challenging it was for @data.characters.female_child_4.name and @data.characters.female_caregiver_2.name.

It can be hard for parents and teens to talk about boyfriends and girlfriends.

Let‚Äôs look at an example of how this can happen calmly.
rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.female_caregiver_1.name, can I talk to you about something?
rows.character_2_text: (calmly) Sure, my darling. What is the matter?

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.male_child_1.name wants us to study together tomorrow. I really like him but I am not sure what to do.

character_2_text.eng: (ü§î_thinking to herself_) How has my daughter grown up so fast? What now? Take a deep breath‚Ä¶

rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.male_child_1.name wants us to study together tomorrow. I really like him but I am not sure what to do.
rows.character_2_text: (ü§î_thinking to herself_) How has my daughter grown up so fast? What now? Take a deep breath‚Ä¶

character_1_text.eng:
(Calmly) Thank you for sharing this with me, @data.characters.female_child_1.name. I know that you like @data.characters.male_child_1.name a lot, he is a charming boy and he does great at school, but you are only 16 and he is 18.

I feel worried that it is not safe for you to be alone with him. He might pressure you into doing something that you are not prepared to do.

I don‚Äôt want to tell you who you can see but we need to have some rules about how you spend time together.

rows.character_1_text:
(Calmly) Thank you for sharing this with me, @data.characters.female_child_1.name. I know that you like @data.characters.male_child_1.name a lot, he is a charming boy and he does great at school, but you are only 16 and he is 18.

I feel worried that it is not safe for you to be alone with him. He might pressure you into doing something that you are not prepared to do.

I don‚Äôt want to tell you who you can see but we need to have some rules about how you spend time together.

character_1_text.eng: What do you think would be a fair rule about how you spend time together?

character_2_text.eng: How about, we can spend time together if there is an adult with us?

rows.character_1_text: What do you think would be a fair rule about how you spend time together?
rows.character_2_text: How about, we can spend time together if there is an adult with us?

character_1_text.eng: That would be fine as long as his parents also know. I will chat with his mother when I see her later today. And after you get back, we can talk about how it went.

character_2_text.eng: (hugs @data.characters.female_caregiver_1.name) Okay. Thank you for coming up with a plan together, @data.characters.female_caregiver_1.name.

quiz_1_question.eng:
Who should start the conversation about body changes and intimate relationships? 

(Try selecting each option for more tips)

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
This is not quite right. Try another option.

Remember, friends can sometimes mislead or have wrong information themselves.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng:
This is not quite right. Try another option.

Your teen might feel uncomfortable or scared to start that conversation with you.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
Yes, you will probably need to start the conversation. It is okay to feel uncomfortable. Be open and use the correct words ( for example: use words like breasts, penis and/or vagina).

It can help to practise the conversation with a friend (maybe another friend with a teenager) or relative, and get more information from your community health worker or social worker. You can better guide your teen when you have the right information.

It is okay to not know all the answers as well. If your teen asks you a question, you can always say: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know about that. Let me get some answers and come back to you about it.‚Äù

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1:
This is not quite right. Try another option.

Remember, friends can sometimes mislead or have wrong information themselves.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2:
This is not quite right. Try another option.

Your teen might feel uncomfortable or scared to start that conversation with you.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3:
Yes, you will probably need to start the conversation. It is okay to feel uncomfortable. Be open and use the correct words ( for example: use words like breasts, penis and/or vagina).

It can help to practise the conversation with a friend (maybe another friend with a teenager) or relative, and get more information from your community health worker or social worker. You can better guide your teen when you have the right information.

It is okay to not know all the answers as well. If your teen asks you a question, you can always say: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know about that. Let me get some answers and come back to you about it.‚Äù
rows.quiz_1_question:
Who should start the conversation about body changes and intimate relationships? 

(Try selecting each option for more tips)

quiz_1_question.eng:
When is the right time to start talking about body changes and intimate relationships?

(Try selecting each option for more tips)

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: When you find out they have a boyfriend or girlfriend

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
This is not quite right. Try another option. 

It is important that your teen knows about body changes and intimate relationships before they reach that stage, so they are ready and can make good choices.

If you discover that your teen is having sex, try to share your feelings or worries in a calm way so you can find a way forward together. Anger towards your teen will make them less likely to open up with you about hard topics.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng:
This is not quite right. Try another option. 

From the age of 10, children start to enter the puberty stage and need to already know about how their bodies and feelings may change.

This will also help them cope better with sexual feelings safely.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
That's right!  

From the age of 10, children start to enter the puberty stage and need to already know about how their bodies and feelings may change.

This will also help them cope better with sexual feelings safely.

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng:
That's right. 

Discussions around body changes and intimate relationships can start early, before the age of 9, by responding to questions a child may have.

You do not need to go into detail ‚Äì just answer their questions in a simple and honest way that works for their age.

Discussions around body changes and intimate relationships can start early, before the age of 9, by responding to questions a child may have.

You do not need to go into detail ‚Äì just answer their questions in a simple and honest way that works for their age.

quiz_1_question.eng:
How can I best keep my teen safe?

(Try selecting each option for more tips)

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: I determine what my teen can and cannot do

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
This may not work. Try another option.

When we are too controlling, our teens may end up doing the things we do not want them to do.

When we give our teens space to make their own decisions and guide them, they generally behave more responsibly.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: I keep information or bad influences away from them

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng:
This may not work. Try another option.

Teens get information and pressure from many different sources that we cannot control.

It is our role as parents to prepare them and guide them well, so they can learn how to tell the difference between good and bad information, and be confident to make their own decisions.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: I build a healthy trusting relationship with my teen

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
That's right.

Your teen will trust you, when they feel you trust them. They are more likely to ask for advice or share when they have a problem if they are used to talking to you.

Praise and thank your teen whenever they share, and avoid judging their questions or behaviour so they feel safe to come to you again and again.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: I discuss consequences and solutions with my teen

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng:
That's right.

To make a good decision, we have to think through the consequences. When you have a problem, have an open discussion with your teen. Listen to each other‚Äôs opinions and discuss solutions together.

Every challenge is an opportunity to help your teen understand that each action has consequences and you can work together to find a solution.

When you work through a tricky situation or conversation together, remember to praise and recognise yourselves for your great teamwork.

quiz_1_option_5_text.eng: I emphasize that pressure is never okay

quiz_1_feedback_5.eng:
That's right.

To stay safe, your teen needs to understand the difference between respectful behaviours and relationships, and unhealthy ones.

A respectful relationship is when we feel cared for, involved in decision making, happy and safe. An unhealthy relationship is when we feel pressured to do something, uncomfortable with decisions or actions, or unsafe in any other way.

In any relationship or sexual activity, you should never be pushed or convinced to do something you do not feel comfortable with, and you should never force others either. You can learn more about this in the Staying Safe module.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1:
This may not work. Try another option.

When we are too controlling, our teens may end up doing the things we do not want them to do.

When we give our teens space to make their own decisions and guide them, they generally behave more responsibly.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2:
This may not work. Try another option.

It is our role as parents to prepare them and guide them well, so they can learn how to tell the difference between good and bad information, and be confident to make their own decisions.

Praise and thank your teen whenever they share, and avoid judging their questions or behaviour so they feel safe to come to you again and again.

How can I best keep my teen safe?

(Try selecting each option for more tips)
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: I determine what my teen can and cannot do
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: I keep information or bad influences away from them
rows.quiz_1_option_3_text: I build a healthy trusting relationship with my teen
rows.quiz_1_option_4_text: I discuss consequences and solutions with my teen
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4:
That's right.

To make a good decision, we have to think through the consequences. When you have a problem, have an open discussion with your teen. Listen to each other‚Äôs opinions and discuss solutions together.

Every challenge is an opportunity to help your teen understand that each action has consequences and you can work together to find a solution.

When you work through a tricky situation or conversation together, remember to praise and recognise yourselves for your great teamwork.
rows.quiz_1_option_5_text: I emphasize that pressure is never okay
rows.quiz_1_feedback_5:
That's right.

To stay safe, your teen needs to understand the difference between respectful behaviours and relationships, and unhealthy ones.

A respectful relationship is when we feel cared for, involved in decision making, happy and safe. An unhealthy relationship is when we feel pressured to do something, uncomfortable with decisions or actions, or unsafe in any other way.

In any relationship or sexual activity, you should never be pushed or convinced to do something you do not feel comfortable with, and you should never force others either. You can learn more about this in the Staying Safe module.

quiz_1_question.eng:
How can I help prevent my teen from having sex too young?

(Try selecting each option for more tips)

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: Keep any information about sex away from them

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Try another option.

Teenagers get right and wrong information about sex from many different sources at an early age, including school, their friends, and social media.

Knowing about sex does not mean they are having sex themselves already. Having good information can help teenagers understand sex, be clear about safe and unsafe interactions with others, and why they may want to choose to wait to have sex.

Not knowing about sex can lead to problems, for example when teens do not understand how pregnancy happens or what risks sex can have.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: Forbid them to have a boyfriend or girlfriend

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng:
Try another option.

Your teen may have a boyfriend or girlfriend without telling you.

If you push them to hide their relationships, they may not come to you when they have questions or problems (about their partner or other things), and they may end up in dangerous situations without you knowing.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: Have an open discussion on how and why they could wait

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
That's right.

Teens are finding their way in life. They are looking around them ‚Äì to friends and media ‚Äì to figure out who they are now and what they want for their future. Because of this, other people may push them to do things they are not ready for.

Try to discuss and explore together how they could wait to have sex until they are ready and in a safe relationship, and can better understand and handle any consequences. Be calm and focus on guiding them to make healthy decisions, even if they are not the decisions you would choose to make.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1:
Try another option.

Teenagers get right and wrong information about sex from many different sources at an early age, including school, their friends, and social media.

Knowing about sex does not mean they are having sex themselves already. Having good information can help teenagers understand sex, be clear about safe and unsafe interactions with others, and why they may want to choose to wait to have sex.

Not knowing about sex can lead to problems, for example when teens do not understand how pregnancy happens or what risks sex can have.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are this week‚Äôs takeaway skills to help you discuss body changes and intimate relationships!

text_2.eng: Discussing body changes and intimate relationships can be uncomfortable, but it is so important in order to keep your teen happy, healthy and safe. Here are some skills to help you get started:

section_1_text.eng:
Build a strong relationship with your teen by spending time with them and showing them you trust them. Create a safe, encouraging space, and avoid judging them.

That will make your teen share their questions and worries with you, when they need advice or are in a potentially dangerous situation.

section_2_text.eng:
Your teen may feel scared, so as parents we need to start the conversation on body changes and intimate relationships.

Start young (before 9 years) by answering their questions in a simple and honest way. That builds your and your child‚Äôs confidence.

It is okay to feel uncomfortable. Be open, use the correct words, and get more information for yourself if you do not have all the answers.

section_3_text.eng:
Your teen will get information about sex from many different sources. When they feel safe and comfortable with you, you can guide them and build their ability to find good information and solutions now and in the future.

Help them think about the consequences of behaviours (without shame or blame). Make sure they understand that they should never feel pressured (or pressure someone else) into any sexual activity or relationship.

Get help or information for yourself from other adults or medical professionals.

rows.section_1_text:
Build a strong relationship with your teen by spending time with them and showing them you trust them. Create a safe, encouraging space, and avoid judging them.

That will make your teen share their questions and worries with you, when they need advice or are in a potentially dangerous situation.

Help them think about the consequences of behaviours (without shame or blame). Make sure they understand that they should never feel pressured (or pressure someone else) into any sexual activity or relationship.

Get help or information for yourself from other adults or medical professionals.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Small actions, big results! Parents who practice their module skills at home get better results.

Your home practice this week is to read and discuss this module's stories together with your teen, and let it spark a conversation about body changes and intimate relationships.

rows.text_2: Placeholder text for Anna: Can we connect this step somehow to the sex talk / my new boyfriend stories? Previously, the two stories were linked.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Placeholder text - Anna can you provide outtro summary

media_title.eng: Placeholder - context needed here Anna (this is a media title of teen testimonial)

media_transcript.eng:
As teens, we hear all these things about sex from others at school and on the internet. I thought all those things were true, and I was doing a lot of things secretly, because my friends were pushing me and I was afraid of what my mother would say.

When I did this app together with my mother, I realised that so many things I learnt were not true. I learnt I can get better information and I learnt others should never push me to do things I do not want to do. My mother and I can talk about these things now. I wish we could have done that when I was younger, because it would have helped me a lot, but I am still glad we can talk today. Whenever I have a question or problem now, I know I can ask my mother and she will help me think of answers and solutions together.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Placeholder text - Anna can you provide outtro summary
rows.media_title: Placeholder - context needed here Anna (this is a media title of teen testimonial)
rows.media_transcript:
As teens, we hear all these things about sex from others at school and on the internet. I thought all those things were true, and I was doing a lot of things secretly, because my friends were pushing me and I was afraid of what my mother would say.

When I did this app together with my mother, I realised that so many things I learnt were not true. I learnt I can get better information and I learnt others should never push me to do things I do not want to do. My mother and I can talk about these things now. I wish we could have done that when I was younger, because it would have helped me a lot, but I am still glad we can talk today. Whenever I have a question or problem now, I know I can ask my mother and she will help me think of answers and solutions together.
